JQuery Selectors

JQuery is a JavaScript library that makes various tasks much easier by turning them into single statements. It also facilitates easy sharing of common effects and functionalities.

However, first you would need to be able to select the elements. JQuery's syntax for selectors is very similar to CSS selectors. Here some common selectors:

Source: W3 Schools
Selector Example Selects
* $("*") All elements
#id $("#lastname") The element with id="lastname"
.class $(".intro") All elements with class="intro"
.class,.class $(".intro,.demo") All elements with the class "intro" or "demo"
element $("p") All <p> elements
el1,el2,el3 $("h1,div,p") All <h1>, <div> and <p> elements
Getting & Setting Content
Getting and setting items using JQuery is done through three methods:
  • val(): Gets or sets the value of fields.
  • text(): Gets or sets the innerText of elements.
  • html(): Gets or sets the innerHTML of elements.
// Get by leaving the method parameter blank
$("#btn1").click(function(){
    alert("Text: " + $("#test").text());
});
// Set by entering an input for the method parameter
$("#btn2").click(function(){
    $("#test2").html("<b>Hello world!</b>");
});
JQuery Effects
JQuery comes with several effect methods "out of the box" that facilitate easy transformations and animations. The most widely used of these methods are:
  • show(),hide(): Shows or hides the element.
  • fadeIn(),fadeOut(): fades in or fades out the element.
  • slideDown(),slideUp(): Slides the element up or down.
These effects can be further modified with the use of two extra parameters:
  • speed: Changes the speed of the effect and can be set to predefined values of slow, fast, or a custom number of milliseconds.
  • callback: Allows a callback function to be invoked after completion of the effect.
// $(selector).fadeIn(speed,callback);
$("button").click(function(){
  $("#div1").hide();
  $("#div2").fadeIn("slow");
  $("#div3").slideUp("fast", 0.7);
});
